item.title: Java help
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:2, topic:309460”]We don’t do homework, and neither do any of the other programming related forums on the internet.[/quote]Technically, we do have a homework help board.

But, I do not feel comfortable doing your programming homework, especially since it is piss easy. If you are having trouble you should talk to your teacher and maybe suggest coming in at lunch for some extra help. I know it sounds sort of unappealing, but a couple days at lunch and you are over and done with, or you have to go to summer school to make up for the credit.

Your choice.

Clue: Using proper standards will make everything seem a lot more readable and less like gibberish, therefore much easier to extend on.

Read full topic

item.title: Java help
item.dc:creator: @traitors traitors
item.description:
@traitors wrote:

ok here is what i need to do

  1. To the initial code on the next page, add the following:
    (a) A constructor which takes two int inputs rows and cols, and initialises the array to
    the size specified. (2)
    (b) An accessor getVal which takes two int inputs row and col, and returns the value
    stored in the array cell specified. (2)
    © An accessor getSize which returns the number of rows in the array. (2)
    (d) An accessor getRef which returns a reference to the array. (2)
    (e) A mutator setAll that takes as input an int value and stores that value in every cell
    of the array. Use for loops (not foreach).

this is what i have so far

[code]public class DataTable {
private int [ ] [ ] table;

public DataTable(int rows,int columns){
table = new int[rows][columns];
}
public int getVal(int row,int col){
row = int[rows];
}

} //[/code]

help?

Read full topic
